August 29, 1962.

Mrs. C. H. Darwent,
Manitou Lodge,
Watrous, Sask.

Dear Mrs. Darwent:

I wish to thank you for sending us the very interesting account of your pioneer experiences. Without accounts like the one you prepared for us, it would be most difficult for the historian to recapture the experiences that the people who pioneered this country went through. We are grateful that you were able to help us preserve some of the pioneer story. Your account will be kept permanently along with the pioneer questionnaires you answered some time ago.

I am very glad that you have found such a nice home.

Best wishes to you in your retirement.

Yours sincerely,

D. H. Bocking
Asst. Prov. Archivist

We spent the last night in England at Ellinville at Shattam, with the train early in the morning for Liverpool. Father and I went who were not quite 2 yrs old, etc we walked up the lane from Ellinville and her Mother Mrs Parker Wood at the front door and sang "God be with till we meet again." I did not feel sad as I thought we were only going for ten years, and then would go back to our Home in England. PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

An Aid in the Preparation of the History

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as hundreds of others. The questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove more useful to you than they do to others. You may find it easier to answer the questions in detail, or describe particular experiences if they help you to answer them.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or supply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Western Canadian Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did They Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here and one will be sent to you.

Western Canadian Archives Questionnaire No. 2, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did They Do?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here and one will be sent to you.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

One Homestead moved to Australia because the climate was better; another went back to the United States where they came from. Of the original settler, they have all moved away now except 2 who were born there. My son and a neighbor born there in 1907.

The prairie land being broken, and changing from Horse and Buggies to wonderful cars, also changing from the sod shack to lovely home with electricity, running water etc. From Prairie trails to paved road, from small stores to modern stores.
